thread.title: H.S. football: Park Ridge downs Becton, 32-0 - Football
thread.title_full: H.S. football: Park Ridge downs Becton, 32-0 - Football - NorthJersey.com

author: GREG MATTURA
title: H.S. football: Park Ridge downs Becton, 32-0 - Football
text:
EAST RUTHERFORD – Park Ridge now stands at the doorstep of a division title and possible No. 1 seed for the state football playoffs.
The Owls’ 32-0 victory over Becton on Friday night places them in position to earn no worse than a share of the NJIC Meadowlands Division title and no less than the No. 2 seed in North 1, Group 1.
"We set goals at the beginning of the year to challenge for a league title, to make the state playoffs, and possibly challenge for a state championship," said Park Ridge coach Tom Curry Jr., "and they keep adding goals each and every single week – it’s great."
Park Ridge (6-1) can reach its goal of a Meadowlands title and likely two home playoff games with a home victory Friday over Secaucus. The Owls are tied for first in the Meadowlands with Hasbrouck Heights.
"This was great, this was one of the best performances we’ve had in a while," Curry said, "but it’s all for naught if we don’t come out next week against Secaucus and play our ‘A’ game."
"The league title was our first goal when we got into camp this year," said Owls senior quarterback Evan Matthews, "and the fact that we’re so close to accomplishing that, I think it speaks to how hard we’ve worked."
Meanwhile, the chance for Becton (5-2) to grab a piece of the Meadowlands title is no longer in its hands, and it needs a home win Friday over North Arlington to remain in the hunt for a North 1, Group 1 bid.
Matthews led Park Ridge on Friday by tossing four touchdown passes, including three to junior receiver Joshua Lewis, and also running for a score.
Park Ridge dominated the first half and led, 20-0, gaining command with a three-touchdown second quarter against a Becton team that had held five of its first six opponents to eight points or less.
The Owls amassed 241 yards in the opening half and Matthews threw three TD passes in the second quarter, with the first going to senior receiver Greg Kolaros and the next two to Lewis.
Park Ridge took a 7-0 lead at 9:29 of the second quarter when Matthews capped an 11-play, 80-yard drive by tossing an 8-yard TD pass to Kolaros.
The Owls extended their lead to 14-0 with 2:41 left in the half when Matthews hooked up with Lewis for a 67-yard TD.
Park Ridge stretched the lead to 20-0 with 1:59 left in the half when Matthews threw to Lewis for a 28-yard score.
Becton’s biggest gain was a 49-yard pass from sophomore quarterback Michael Bolwell to senior Gianni Failla that would have been a TD if not for a tackle by junior linebacker Tom Morgan. Also, the defense set up the Owls’ third score: an interception by sophomore Gabriel Robles.
"All aspects of the game, special teams, defense, offense, we showed up," Curry said.
